Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild directly asks their grandmother for help and advice with a serious concern in their life.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A major news network has just called for an immediate on-air comment to counter misinformation in a breaking story.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was settling in with my granddaughter at the kitchen table. She looked up at me, her eyes wide and uncertain, and said, “Grandma, can I talk to you about something important?” I could see the worry on her face, the kind that only comes when you’re young and the world feels too big. I reached for her hand, ready to listen, when my phone rang again—this time, the caller ID flashed the name of the news network. They needed me, right now, to speak on air and set the record straight about the cause I’d spent years fighting for. I could hear the urgency in the producer’s voice, the weight of responsibility pressing on my chest. My granddaughter’s hand trembled in mine, her need for comfort and guidance so clear. But the world outside needed me too, needed my voice to cut through the noise. I felt torn, my heart pulled in two directions, each demanding all of me at once.
